Dear user harmagedon,

I sent the following to you on 14th December, but since the message has obviously not got through to you, I feel compelled to repeat it:

We note that you have performed more than 100.000 edits in the past three weeks, most of them by removing "created_by" tags from existing objects.

First of all, let me say that there is probably a misunderstanding about the function of the "changeset comment" field on your part; this field is not meant for adding URLs to external web sites, but instead for documenting your edits so that others can see what you have done. In your case, a proper changeset comment would have been "removed created_by tags".

Secondly, while it is true that the use of "created_by" tags on nodes and ways is not encouraged any more, we have decided not to remove them automatically because this generates many unnecessary change events.

We would thus ask you to reduce your editing activity to areas where you have valuable contributions other than removing existing tags.

Thank you
Frederik Ramm

It looks like your doing some sort of import that has gone wrong - you have ways spanning multiple continents. See, for example:

Please stop the import and fix the data before trying again. There is a test API available at api06.dev.openstreetmap.org if you want to test your code. The imports working group would also be happy to help if this is an import.

Incidentally, it would be better to add nodes and ways in the same changeset rather than uploading the nodes first and then the ways.

Your attempts to clean up your previous edits seem to be doing just as much damage, if not more, as the original edits.

In particular you seem to be removing nodes which weren't added by you, and modifying the ways which used them to remove the nodes in question. For example:

http://www.openstreetmap.org/browse/node/47172597/history

has been removed from:

http://www.openstreetmap.org/browse/way/5865576/history

despite the fact that neither object had previously been touched by you.

Please seek help from the imports working group before you do any more of these bulk edits - they are causing serious damage.

Thanks,

Tom

Dear user mk408,

I am writing to you on behalf of the OSMF data working group. We deal with disputes, vandalism, and copyright infringement. We have received a number of complaints about some of your edits, from different users.

The core issue seems to be a dispute about you and a number of other users in the United States about what excatly constitutes a "tertiary" highway. We do not intend to get involved in the dispute; such disputes are generally, and should be, resolved by the community members through discussion.

What we object to is the fact that you seem to refuse to participate in the resolution of these disputes; instead you use automated edits to revert any change that does not match your personal opinion.

Please understand that OpenStreetMap is a community effort. Only by working together, and amicably resolving our disputes, can we achieve our goals. There is no room in OpenStreetMap for people who believe that they are always right and stand above discussion.

We urge you to discuss the matter of road classification with your peers in any of the available ways - e.g. on the talk-us mailing list. We expect you to refrain from reverting the edits of others until an the matter has been resolved.

This message blocks your account, but only until you log in to www.openstreetmap.org; you will be able to edit normally afterwards. We sincerely hope that we will not take further measures, and that you and your fellow mappers manage to solve this issue like the grown-up people you are.

Frederik Ramm a.k.a. woodpeck
for the Data Working Group

Dear user Supt_of_printing,

we have had complaints about your edits of intersections in Australia. It seems that you edits are guided by a desire to make an intersection look nice on the map, rather than accurately reflect reality.

In OSM, looking nice on the map is not the data editor's business - when we edit data, we try and make it as precise as possible. This includes, for example, setting the oneway property even if it is obvious on the ground that a section of road is oneway; it includes properly joining roads even if this might lead to a name printed more frequently, and so on. Making this look nice on the rendered map is the business of the renderer, and data must not be misrepresented just to look nice - remember that there are tons of different renderers, and there are also routing engines for which certain aspects of the data are of critical importance to navigate the junction.

Also, you have been made aware of the problems with your edits and you have reacted in a defiant way; but OSM is a community project where we all have to work together. If you find that a significant number of users disagree with your work, you cannot just ignore them and continue. You must enter a dialogue and search for a solution together.

Your account is not blocked and you can continue editing normally after you have logged in. I must ask you, however, to refrain from your way of visually "polishing" junctions in the future, and discuss the matter with your fellow mappers on the talk-au mailing list.

If you continue with this kind of edits, we will have to block your account.

Regards
Frederik Ramm a.k.a. woodpeck
for the Data Working Group

Некоторые из ваших тегов и отображения подходы необычного в крайности. Важно сопоставить в разумных ожиданий других картографов в этой области.

  • Бесполезные комментарии изменений

Ерунда текст изменений эквивалентно к обману и недопустима. В дальнейшем, использовать надлежащие подробными комментариями изменений.

Вы должны взаимодействовать с другими картографами, когда они делают хорошие вопросы о вашей вере отображения. Пожалуйста, присоединяйтесь с другими членами сообщества для решения вопросов в ваш вклад немедленно. Пожалуйста, сообщите данные рабочей группы, когда вы выполнили требования выше.

С уважением, Ричард Weait, от имени Данные рабочей группы

Dear eXmajor,

Your tagging / mapping selections continue to puzzle the community.

http://www.openstreetmap.org/browse/way/161658161 - highway = path as an outline of an area is incorrect Use highway = path for a constructed path from one place to another.

http://www.openstreetmap.org/browse/way/161655302 - self intersecting polygon is incorrect. Joining distinct polygons with thin "channels" is incorrect. Either use distinct polygons, or a larger simple polygon.

http://www.openstreetmap.org/browse/way/161655311 - highway = *_link form incorrect - dual carriageway incorrect - highway = tertiary unlikely The _link form is for short connectors, not entire ways. A single carriageway is modeled as a single way, not two one-way ways. This road, and many of your others are inappropriately promoted to tertiary or above. Use highway = service for alleys / driveways. use highway = unclassified / residential for the least prominent public road network. Use tertiary and above only for roads more substantial than those.

You must engage with the OpenStreetMap community and map by consensus rather then attempting to impose your own idiosyncratic style on the map.

If you don't like the way that data appears when rendered, learn how to use other rendering tools to fix the appearance for yourself. Do not break that data to meet your rendering expectations.

Others may have already created a rendering that you prefer.

Best regards, Richard.

eXmajor has been blocked, again, for failing to communicate with other community members in good faith.

All contributions by eXmajor and related accounts are subject to reversion without further discussion.

Hello,

I noticed you were importing Spanish Cadastre data in http://www.openstreetmap.org/browse/changeset/11502848 and http://www.openstreetmap.org/browse/changeset/11503887

There are a few problems with this. The first is that the problems with many multipolygons appear to have not been fixed. These problems were that too many multipolygons were being generated for what was a simple geometry.

The second problem is that you are importing features other than highways and leisure=park. Although the tags have not yet been uploaded, this is evident from where the nodes are. As pointed out http://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/imports/2012-March/001313.html only those features were consulted on with the imports@ list. If you want import more data you need to propose a new import.

This block is set to last until you log on to read the message. When you have done that, please revert your imports. If you do not feel able to revert your import let me know and I can do it for you.

If you have questions please contact me via a message or the DWG at data@osmfoundation.org

Paul Norman

For the Data Working Group

Dear user WorstFixer,

please stop doing large-scale edits. You are violating our policy for mechanical edits.

You have to discuss such edits with the community before you do them.

OSM is a community project. You cannot make such edits across the worlds without talking to people BEFORE. "Will not discuss with trolls" is not an acceptable response.

An appropriate forum to discuss such edits is the talk list, at listinfo.openstreetmap.org/talk.

Thank you Frederik Ramm (for the OSMF data working group)
Please read the comment I added to your diary and adhere to our policies.

Dear User ZeGermanata,

we saw that you added a number of imaginary roads, railroads, and other features to the OpenStreetMap database in the Menominee area.

Please be aware that you are editing the live database in OSM. Your edits will directly go up on the main page, on people's GPS maps, and numerous other web pages. This is not a place for play!

We will remove the problematic edits but in the future, please only add information to the OSM database that is indeed correct.

Thank you Frederik Ramm a.k.a. woodpeck for the OSMF data working group

Dear user chicago-buildings,

as you probably know, data imports have to be discussed (and agreed upon) before they are started (usually on the "talk" list or a regional variant and the "imports" list), and we also request that imports are documented properly on the Wiki. From my perusal of the mailing list and Wiki I could not find the required documentation for your import. Please update the account's user page with information pointing the discussion of your import, and outlining your methods.

Please do not continue your import until you have done so. If a discussion has not taken place yet, then start a discussion and stop your import for the time being.

We will have to revert your import wholesale if you disregard these rules.

Thank you Frederik Ramm (for the Data Working Group)

I noticed you importing MGC data in http://www.openstreetmap.org/browse/changeset/11753610

I wanted to remind you about the import guidelines at http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Import/Guidelines which, among other things, call for imports to be done from an account dedicated to only imports, not from your normal account, and consultation to be done with imports@ and the local community (talk-us@ in this case).

I sent you a message a day ago or so but you have not responded and continued to import, so I've placed this block until log on to ensure that you check your messages before continuing to import.

Paul Norman

Hallo day33,

leider sind Deine Edits in OSM weiterhin grob falsch, und Du hast es versäumt, auf berechtigte Hinweise der Community einzugehen. Deine Changeset-Kommentare sind nichtssagend. Deine Edits geben nicht den tatsächlichen Zustand wieder und sind daher für OSM so nicht geeignet.

Bitte überdenke Dein Handeln, und sprich in Forum oder Mailingliste oder auf einem Stammtisch mit Leuten über das Projekt, um zu verstehen, wie Du sinnvoll beitragen kannst.

Bitte sei Dir dessen bewusst, dass absichtlich verfälschende Edits keineswegs ein Scherz sind, sondern einen Verstoss gegen unsere AGB und gegen geltende Gesetze in den meisten Ländern darstellen.

Bye Frederik Ramm a.k.a. woodpeck

I noticed you were conducting an import or mechanical edit with this changeset. The OSM Sysadmins have requested that all imports, automated edits, bulk edits and bots be stopped until the redaction process has ended.

More information can be found on the mailing lists.

This block will last until you log on to osm.org to ensure you read it.

I've checked with the sysadmins about the server load from fixing broken imports and please go ahead and revert this one if it is in anyway incomplete. If help is needed, contact the imports@ mailing list and/or talk@, but the import guidelines say that if you do not know how to fix an import you do not import, so please keep that in mind for future imports.

As a general reminder, the other import guidelines can be found on the wiki. These include

  • appropriate documentation
  • consultation with the local community and the imports@ mailing list
  • imports being from a dedicated account
  • other technical requirements

Additionally best practice is to indicate a source tag on any import changesets

Dear user _sev,

I am contacting you in my role as a member of the OSMF data working group which deals with mapping disputes.

We have received a complaint about your replacing Russian with Ukrainian names in the Crimea, where Ukrainian is the official language but Russian is the language spoken on the ground.

Please explain your actions.

Until this matter is resolved, we must ask you not stop editing names (or reverting edits) in the Crimea.

Thank you Frederik Ramm for the OSMF data working group.

Dear user jcb1281,

I'm unsure if you are aware of that but you are making fictional changes to our live database which is viewed and used by hundreds of thousands of people around the world.

Your changeset comments say "please do not use" but there is no private copy of OSM just for you with your fictional changes - these changes affect the one, central, database that everyone is using.

Please refrain from uploading fictional edits in the future. You can edit an OSM file locally on your computer and then make a map from that - but don't upload it for the world to use.

Frederik Ramm a.k.a. woodpeck for the OSMF data working group.

Hallo, es ist schon, dass ihr bei eurem Projekt auf OpenStreetMap (OSM) setzen wollt.

Jedoch ist mir aufgefallen, dass eure Edits nicht ganz dem Entsprechen, wie es in OSM üblich ist. Ich geh mal davon aus, dass dies nicht eure Absicht war. Hier einige Beispiele:

Ein Objekt ist bereits in der Datenbank von OSM vorhanden und ihr setzt das Objekt noch ein zweites Mal in die Datenbank rein.

Ein Editor sollte im Changeset mitteilen, mit welchem Editor die Daten hochgeladen wurden ( created_by= ) ebenso wäre ein aussagekräftiger Changesetkommentar wünschenswert.

Der Key opening_hours hat auch ein vorgegebenes Schema, nach dem die Werte eingetragen werden und ist kein Freitextfeld. Ohne die Einhaltung des Schemas können die Informationen nicht sinnvoll ausgewertet werden und haben dann auch keinen Nutzen.

Es wäre schön, wenn ihr mit der OSM-Community in Kontakt treten würdet und über die Probleme sprechen würdet.

Viele Grüße,

Henning Scholland für die DataWorkingGroup

Dear user fredtz,

your first edits to the OpenStreetMap database are wildly inappropriate (renaming places to "This is an Azerbaijan territory" etc.) - please stop that.

With regard to the "name" tag, OSM observes the "on the ground rule", i.e. it doesn't count what the world knows something under - the name used locally, on signs etc., should be used. Other, alternative names may be placed in the "name:languagecode" tags.

Best wishes Frederik Ramm OSMF Data Working Group.

you have recently deleted and replaced, or renamed, a number of Mormon churches in OSM, and named them "LDS cult".

Dear users Komяpa and Willi2006,

we notice that you have been involved in something that looks like a starting edit war in Thailand.

Komяpa seems to have:

  1. traced a number of buildings from Bing;
  2. changed a number of highway types e.g. from "track" to "unclassified" in order to "fix" routing bugs;
  3. created streets in order to compensate for OSRM's inability to route across "highway=services" areas.

Willi2006 seems to have been enraged by this incursion into his home turf, and performed a wholsale revert of all edits.

I have reverted Willi2006's revert but this is not intended to be the last word on the issue.

I would ask BOTH parties to stop edit warring and explain yourselves.

About the buildings:

Komяpa, I think everybody may trace buildings from Bing anywhere, and Willi2006 is wrong to ask you for "proof that these buildings really exist" - instead, someone DELETING a building should have proof the these buildings don't exist. However, I think an armchair mapper should also respect the will of the local community and if the local community says "we don't want armchair traced buildings in our area" then please don't do it. Willi2006, do other members of the local community back up your request of "no armchair tracing of buildings", or is it you alone?

About the changes in highway types:

Komяpa, I do not believe that aerial imagery is good enough to distinguish an unclassified road from a highway=track. I think you should not make such changes based on aerial imagery alone, especially if you don't know the area.

About the service areas:

Komяpa, if there are service areas not recognized by OSRM, which therefore lead to "islands", then maybe OSRM is in need of fixing. I am currently unsure whether it is usual to have actual service lanes across areas tagged highway=services; in any case this is something that the local community should decide.

About the reverts:

Willi2006, what you did was not ok; you completely reverted lots of edits into which others have invested quite some time. Thailand is not yours alone. Have you conferred with other members of the local community or at least others who frequently edit in Thailand? The JOSM reverter plugin should not be used on a large scale like you did without discussing the issue in a larger group first. I am also very unhappy that you used a misleading changeset tag on all your reverts.

I am copying this message to Russ and Stefan who both seem to have made prior edits in the area as well. I would be happy if you could find an amicable solution to this. As I said, Komяpa, I believe that nobody should be "nannying" an area but still someone who lives there trumps those who armchair-map from Bing; I know you made your edits with the best intentions but if the people on the ground don't want your help then maybe it would be ok to just help elsewhere.

Bye Frederik Ramm aka woodpeck for the OSMF data working group.

Themegamaster9000,

you have once again changed the "place" tag of a couple of very small settlements to "city". You have send me personal messages saying "Don't Change Into United States No More" and you have created a changeset comment of "Don't change anything" (http://www.openstreetmap.org/browse/changeset/16022766).

It seems that there is a deep misunderstanding here.

OpenStreetMap is a collectively created database of facts (not fiction).

The common use of the "place" tag is documented on our Wiki here: http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:place. For "place=city", the page says: "The largest urban settlements in the territory, normally including the national, state and provincial capitals."

You have applied place=city, among other things, to a hamlet by the name of "Grappes Bluff" in Louisiana, which is certainly not among the largest urban settlements in its area.

Please understand that what you contribute to OSM has to be based in fact. OSM is not for fiction, and if you want to invent cities you will have to do that elsewhere.

A decision has been reached on the turn restriction dispute referred to the DWG by yourself, Paul Johnson, and multiple other members of the community. This decision took an extended amount of time due to the investigation and multiple bodies the decision went through. The final decision has been endorsed by the OSMF board.

The decision has been made to ban you. This is not a decision that was taken lightly. This is an indefinite ban.

The full text of the DWG recommendation to the board is available at http://www.osmfoundation.org/wiki/File:DWG_NE2_Turn_Restriction_dispute.pdf but the executive summary is as follows:

NE2 is a user in Florida who tends to be in edit wars with others and is involved in many arguments. There was an edit war over a turn restriction earlier this year, which was referred to the DWG by NE2, the other person involved in the dispute, and other members of the US community. NE2's behavior in this dispute was consistent with his past behavior and shows an inability to work with others on what is a crowd-sourcing project. The DWG has recommending/requesting an indefinite (not infinite) ban. This covers both his NE2 and NE3 accounts.

-- Paul Norman

Dear new user,

I am contacting you on behalf of OSMF's data working group. We have received a number of complaints about your edits; people were concerned about your changing of streets to wrong names, and adding data that does not exist in reality.

It is possible that this is a misunderstanding, and you falsely believed that you were editing a private copy of the map.

Please:

  1. Understand that you are editing a live map used by many people - not a private copy where you can do what you want!

  2. When you submit edits, please apply a "changeset comment" so that other users can see what you wanted to achieve with that particular edit.

  3. When other users contact you about your edits, do not ignore them.

  4. Choose an user name that makes sense. OpenStreetMap is a social project and you are participating in a large community by contributing; surely you do not want to do that under the name "hdfgdfgbdfd".

Please write back to data@osmfoundation.org and explain which of your edits, if any, were actually based in fact and should be kept in OpenStreetMap; if we don't hear from you we might have to revert all your edits because they contain a high proportion of inacceptable edits.

Thank you Frederik Ramm

Dear user Quercus1,

i am writing to you on behalf of OSMF's Data Working Group which deals with disputes and vandalism.

You have made a number of unusual contributions to the map in the UK, often deleting correct and valuable information that had been added to the database by others before you. Your changeset comments often seem out of place (e.g. you label something "this is an area of unused land" when the edit that you made was in an inner-city area). Apart from deleting existing data, your edits often don't make sense in that you add objects but don't tag them so nobody knows what your edit is supposed to mean.

I am sure these problems arise from some kind of mistake or misunderstanding, and not from any malicious intent on your part.

I must however ask you to pause your edits now, and either read up on how OpenStreetMap is supposed to work, or seek help from those who contribute frequently. If you want you can read our beginner's guide on the Wiki, or you might want to ask questions on help.openstreetmap.org, or make contact with other UK mappers through the talk-gb mailing list - but please do one of these before you continue, as most of your past edits had to be reverted to repair the damage they did to our database.

Thank you
Frederik Ramm a.k.a. woodpeck
for the OSMF Data Working Group

you have made several edits labelled as "correzione tag telephon" which seem to violate our automated/mechanical edits policy.

Dear user Linusbolzano,

in a recent message I asked you to please add changeset comments to your edits because other mappers often don't understand your motivation or the reasoning behind your edits.

Since you continue to edit in the same vein, and without changeset comments, I repeat my request in this account-blocking message which you will have to read before you can continue mapping. Please comply with this request.

Secondly, in the future please respect the South Tyrol naming policy that the community has created, which is the following: The name tag should be "Italian Name - German Name" in regions with an Italian majority, and "German Name - Italian Name" in regions with a German majority. This is described on http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Multilingual_names#Alto_Adige.2FS.C3.BCdtirol_.28South_Tyrol.29 together with a map showing which regions have which majorities. This map is mandatory until replaced by one based on newer official figures.

Of course you are welcome to add "name:it" tags to anything that has an Italian name - just the plain "name" tag inside South Tyrol must conform to that specification. A lot of your recent edits have violated these rules - changing the name to "Italian Name - German Name" even in regions with a German majority - and will be reverted. Under no circumstances should you change them back.

If you would like to discuss this policy with other mappers from South Tyrol, please join the South Tyrol mailing list (https://lists.openstreetmap.org/listinfo/talk-it-southtyrol) where you can make your point (in Italian or German).

Local knowledge is valued highly in OpenStreetMap and we welcome yours. However, in situations where your knowledge contradicts seemingly well-established facts, we must ask you to supply a suitable proof or at least explain why you are deviating from the standard. For example, in your edit to this node http://www.openstreetmap.org/node/2508795633/history you changed the name of the Bolzano city quarter from "Don Bosco" to "San Giovanni Bosco" even though the linked Wikipedia article clearly speaks of "Don Bosco", and the administration themselves use the email address "donbosco@comune.bolzano.it". This is the type of edit that absolutely requires an explanation in the changeset comment, or it will be reverted.

There are a number of other edits where you have changed a street name from an Italian version frequently found on the web to a more obscure one; this is not necessarily wrong but you owe it to your fellow mappers to explain it to them instead of trying to "overrule" them.

Please respect these rules. Your contributions about Italian names are a welcome and valuable addition to OpenStreetMap and they will improve the map of South Tyrol, but they must harmonise with the community or they will be lost.

Thank you
Frederik Ramm a.k.a. woodpeck
for the OSMF Data Working Group

Elliot,

As we have discussed in the past, in absence of a clear community consensus in the Israeli community about mapping (or not mapping) military areas, eliminating correct data that others have contributed is considered by the DWG to be an act of vandalism of OSM.

You and I discussed this issue in great length in the past, including bringing the general Israeli community in on the discussion. I discussed the matter with several Israeli mappers and posted on the Israeli forums and there was no consensus that your position was the general view of the community. Additionally there was no interest expressed by the Israeli community regarding the offer the OSMF put forth of getting an Israeli lawyer's opinion on the matter of the legality of mapping military areas (which was your argument for their removal).

Therefore I am placing this temporary block on your account (just until you log in and read this message). In addition, we will revert your deletions. In addition, I must warn you that if you continue to purposefully act in ways that we consider vandalism, that your account may be blocked in the future, possibly permanently. Therefore I urge you to stop deleting others contributions to the map.

If you have any questions regarding this matter, please email data@osmfoundation.org

Sincerely,

Serge on behalf of the OSM Data Working Group

Mr Massri,

As we have discussed in the past, removing accurate data from OpenStreetMap is considered an act of vandalism. You have been warned about this behavior several times in the past, including receiving a block recently for it. Because of that, we (the Data Working Group) have decided to block your account for four days and revert your deletions.

Your statement by message that you will continue this behavior, including resorting to illegal means, is equally disturbing. Please consider this an official warning by the DWG that if you continue this behavior that you may find yourself indefinitely blocked from OpenStreetMap.

We value your contributions as an editor and hope that you can continue to be a part of the project- so please discontinue these deletions.

If you have any questions, please contact data@osmfoundation.org

Sincerely,

Serge on behalf of the DWG

Sorin,

After a great deal of debate and discussion, the DWG has come to the decision that we feel that your pattern of edit wars with your fellow mappers, as well as your disrespectful language towards other mappers is disruptive to the project as a whole and we have no alternative other than to separate you from the project. Therefore we have placed an indefinite block on your account. An indefinite block does not have a set time length.

We do not take this decision lightly. We value your long history with the project and the many contributions you have made, but ultimately we believe that OSM is more than simply a data project, it is a community, and as a community our members should expect and receive a certain level of basic respect and politeness that you have continually refused to demonstrate.

The DWG is open to reversing this decision, but you would need to display a sincere desire to work harmoniously with the community, to discontinue the edit wars, and specifically to use respectful language towards your fellow mappers.

You can read the OSM Ban Policy at: http://www.osmfoundation.org/w/index.php?title=Ban_Policy

And you can read your the report that the DWG has made about this decision at:

http://www.osmfoundation.org/w/images/8/8a/DWG_2014-07-10_Special_Romania.pdf

Serge Wroclawski on behalf of the Data Working Group

Dear user liyingben,

we have had a complaint about an import that you did a few months ago (https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/20946274). This import had the following issues:

  • It was not discussed with the community beforehand, but such discussion is required according to our import guidelines http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Import/Guidelines
  • In many cases the names that you imported were already there, leading to duplication
  • All the nodes you imported were tagged place=city, even where they were clearly referring to places of lesser imporance

Therefore, I had to remove that import again. This does not mean that OpenStreetMap is not interested in your contributions in general, or the place name data that you have imported, but imports require diligence and care to get them right. If you are interested, you can join the "imports" mailing list (lists.openstreetmap.org/listinfo/imports) and discuss how to do a place name import properly.

Thank you
Frederik Ramm

Because of the contentious nature of some of your edits, I'm asking you to make meaningful changeset comments on your changesets. That is, when you hit Save, that you fill in that field with a description of what changed, and also ideally why. In addition, it would be great if you filled in the source tag on your changesets, to indicate any secondary data sources that you're using, such as Bing imagery. I'm placing a 0 hour block on your account. That means that you just need to log in and read this message to continue editing. Perimex,

The DWG has been asked to investigate a mapping conflict in relation to the classifications of roads in Poland.

After examining the situation, we have come to the conclusion that your views differ strongly from others in the community, and that is why you are retagging roads en mass, which we see in your edits.

The DWG does not take a stance on which tagging is correct, but we are committed to a process of community harmony. If you believe that your idea of road classification is more correct than the other mappers in Poland, you need to convince them of that through dialog, rather than making mass edits.

We are placing a 0 hour block on your account, not as a punishment, but to ensure that you read this message. At the same time, we need to warn you that continuing to reclassify objects against the wishes of the community could result in your account being blocked in the future.

We value your contributions to the map, and we encourage you to work with the Polish OpenStreetMap community to come to a resolution on this matter that everyone agrees to.

I apologize for my bad Polish, I am using Google Translate to translate this message from English to Polish. The original message is below.

If you have any questions, please do not hesistate to email the DWG at data@osmfoundation.org

Thank you,

Serge Wroclawski on behalf of the OpenStreetMap Data Working Group

Hello,

Your edits (with changeset comments such as "Perl script") have been flagged by other users in changeset discussion comments as destroying data. See for example:

http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28995538

and

http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28883313

In particular, the last of these was 5 days ago and there seems to have been no reply from you in the discussion on the changeset - that's why I'm sending this message as one that you have to read before continuing editing. If you're changing data that other people have added, and they ask you about it, it's only polite that you answer their questions rather than continuing to perform the same sorts of edits.

The changeset comments would also suggest that you are performing a series of mechanical edits. There is a policy in place describing how these must be carried out:

http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Mechanical_Edit_Policy

The very first requirement stated there is "discuss". You need to discuss your proposed changes with the rest of the OpenStreetMap community. If you have discussed these changes, can you please point to where? I don't remember seeing anything on the main "talk" list (the place that the policy says that they should have been discussed).

One more thing, please do use meaningful changeset comments. The ones that you have used (such as "Perl Script", "cancellation" and "corrections") provide absolutely no information about what you changed, or why you changed it. In at least some cases you don't seem to have added any source either.

Of course - it's possible that there may be some misunderstanding here (i.e. you didn't quite understand the scope of the changes that you were making), and if you have any questions at all please do get in contact with us via data@osmfoundation.org . However, if you continue to perform mechanical edits without discussion, cause data problems as mentioned above or not use meaningful changeset comments then you will be blocked from editing for a longer period of time.

Best Regards,

Andy Townsend, on behalf of the OSM Data Working Group

ir

Jei norite pakeisti duomenis, kad kiti žmonės, kurie laiko, ir jie paklausti apie tai, tai tik mandagus, kad jums atsakyti į jų klausimus, o ne toliau atlikti pačios rūšies keitimus.

Į Pakeista komentarai taip pat rekomenduojame, kad jūs atliekate mechaninių keitimus seriją. Yra vietoje politika aprašoma, kaip jie turi būti atliekamas:

Pats pirmasis reikalavimas pareiškė yra "aptarti". Jūs turite aptarti savo siūlomus pakeitimus su OpenStreetMap bendruomenės poilsio. Jei turite aptarti šiuos pokyčius, galite prašome atkreipti į kur? Nepamenu matau nieko apie pagrindinio "talk" sąrašą (vietoje, kad politika sako, kad jie turėjo būti aptarti).

Dar vienas dalykas, atlikite naudojimo prasmingus Pakeista komentarus. Nuoširdžiausi linkėjimai,

Hello andyb109,

Since you started editing OpenStreetMap six weeks ago you've added a lot of "natural=peak" data to OpenStreetMap. Unfortunately quite a lot of them seem to be:

  • duplicates of existing data,

  • misnamed, or

  • in the wrong place

As an example, a few days ago you added:

http://www.openstreetmap.org/node/3371183186/history#map=16/52.9431/-3.2090

This is an almost exact duplicate of:

http://www.openstreetmap.org/node/1860837217

which has been in the database for over two years. I'm sending you this message as one that you have to read before continuing editing because previous attempts at communication have failed. I've previously added to changeset discussions to the following changesets:

http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28284143 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28433302 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28503017 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28504411 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28506109 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28506129 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28508130 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28511355 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28651871 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28688379 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28735192 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28735244 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/28735381

but haven't heard anything back. It's possible that your email is misconfigured, which is why I'm sending this message like in this way.

OpenStreetMap is a shared database. We all collectively benefit from the data that we all individually add to it. Unfortunately, if people add duplicates, misnamed or misplaced things, it devalues the hard work of the people who have previously added valid data. I've deleted some of the duplicates above already; other mappers have deleted some of the others.

It's therefore important that we all take care to get things right. It's not good enough to pick some text on an OS OpenData or out-of-copyright map, find a nearby area of high ground, and assign that name to it regardless of whether in real life it's likely to be called that or not. For example, at this location:

http://www.openstreetmap.org/node/3295427561/history#map=16/52.9261/-3.5377

there is a name "Lily's Wood" on both the OS OpenData and NLS 1:25k OOC maps. However, in this case it is likely that it applies to the wood in which the name occurs:

http://www.openstreetmap.org/way/286819272

which was added to OpenStreetMap some time ago (the clue is in the word "wood").

The NLS 1:25k contours do show a local maximum in the ground level within the wood, but no name distinct name appears to be assigned to it - and therefore no name should be made up for it within OSM. It's also important that meaningful changeset comments are used to help communicate to other mappers how the data was added and why it is valid. In this case (changeset comment "Added new peak") this was not done.

So, once you've read this message please do continue editing OpenStreetmap, but please do make sure that:

  • You don't duplicate existing data that has already been added.

  • You only add data that is valid, correctly named and in the correct location.

  • You don't make up names because you think "this ought to be a named peak" where in reality it is not.

  • You use meaningful changeset comments explaining how any why you know that the edits are valid. Not just something like "Added peak name from OS data", but: which OS data? OS OpenData or an out of copyright map? If an out of copyright map which one, and how do you know that that name is still valid now? If you don't abide by these rules you will be stopped from editing OpenStreetMap.

If you've got any questions please don't hesitate to contact me or anyone else in OSM's data working group by email to data@osmfoundation.org .

Best Regards,

Andy Townsend, on behalf of the OSM Data Working Group.

Dear BitcoinMaps,

it appears that your site allows anonymous users to add data to OpenStreetMap, against a Google Maps background.

This is not acceptable for copyright reasons; firstly, we cannot know where the data comes from and whether the contributing user really is within their rights to add the data to OSM. (We also dislike data contributed under collective accounts beause it means we cannot contact the contributing user.) Secondly, by positioning the node on Google Maps we're deriving location information from their data set which isn't ok either.

Please do not add further POIs to OSM without addressing these points.

Best wishes
Frederik Ramm a.k.a. woodpeck

Hello rbuch703,

I've reverted a series of tag-deleting changesets that you've recently applied.

All of those changesets deleted information that other mappers had previously added to the database. Taking http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/29505495 as an example, You edited http://www.openstreetmap.org/way/84209215/history so that it was no longer clear that the source of the "atv" tag was different to the source of the other tags. You also removed a source code for the IATA tag from http://www.openstreetmap.org/way/185882029 .

I tried to discuss the problem with you in http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/29505495 and http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/29495755 , but there you seem to be disregarding alternative views altogether. You say "And this makes that tag worthless. Deletable.", but you on your own aren't the tag police - changes such as this need to be discussed with the wider community and different people's views taken into account.

Many of the objects in these changesets were possibly created by new and inexperienced mappers, and it's likely that in many cases other local mappers may well decide to change the tagging used - and hopefully discuss how to tag things with them. However, just removing tagging that you don't understand means that there's no easy way for other mappers to improve it in the future - for example, it's very likely that it's possible to tag http://www.openstreetmap.org/way/234050335 better , either based on the note as it stands, or by seeing the note and deciding to go and survey, but no-one will be able to do this if the tag is removed altogether.

I've sent this as a public message that you have to read before continuing editing not to stop you from editing OSM, but so that you have to read this before continuing to do so. Please do continue to edit OpenStreetMap, but don't just delete information that other people on the other side of the continent have added because you don't understand it. Please also do use meaningful changeset comments ("removed invalid tags" is not at all meaningful) that explain what changes you're making and what the source of those changes was. If you continue with edits such as this you WILL be blocked from editing.

If you have any further questions please don't hesitate to contact data@osmfoundation.org.

Best Regards,

Andy Townsend (SomeoneElse) on behalf of the OpenStreetMap Data Working Group.

on 28th May, more than 100 OSM accounts, all named after public transport stations in Verlin, started adding POIs to OpenStreetMap, obviously copying some sort of yellow pages directory, and obviously using some sort of bot or custom-made software.

We must consider this an import, and we don't know anything about your sources and whether they are legal. The fact that you neglected prior discussion with the community and that you are using that many accounts raises a number of questions.

Before you continue, please discuss your plans on either the German OpenStreetMap Forum, or the talk-de mailing list, or the imports mailing list.

The edits you have already made will likely be reverted. Under no circumstances should you create new accounts to circumvent these blocks.

Thank you for your consideration
Frederik Ramm aka woodpeck
OSMF Data Working Group

reason:
Dear user giannhs626,

you seem to be adding fictional data to OpenStreetMap. Please note that OpenStreetMap is not the place for such; we only record facts on the ground. Your edits will be have to be reverted.

Please stop making such fantasy edits in the future.

Thank you
Frederik Ramm
OSMF Data Working Group

Hello andyb109,

You appear to have been adding invalid data to OSM, and not replying to questions about the legitimacy of it. The latest example is http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/31841578 , which appears to be a "natural=peak" at the bottom of a quarry.

I've tried to get in touch many times over the last few months (see https://www.openstreetmap.org/user_blocks/606 and https://www.openstreetmap.org/user_blocks/638 for examples of changesets with discussions on them) but have received no reply.

Please, when you start editing again, do follow all of the requests made in:

http://www.openstreetmap.org/user_blocks/606

It's important that, as a community, OpenStreetMap mappers work together. This means that we need to communicate with each other and reply to each others messages. As I said before, if you don't abide by these rules you will be stopped from editing OpenStreetMap again.

Please do contact me or anyone else in OSM's data working group by email via data@osmfoundation.org .

Best Regards,

Andy Townsend, on behalf of the OSM Data Working Group.

Olá User006,

Parece haver algum desacordo com a classificação de estradas ao redor Linhares. Por exemplo,

http://www.openstreetmap.org/way/328842747/history

foi originalmente adicionado como "highway = primary". Você, então, mudou para "highway = trunk", alguém mudou de volta para "highway = primary", você, em seguida, mudou para "highway = trunk" novamente, e alguém mudou de volta para "highway = primary". Claramente estes "para trás e para a frente" mudanças não conseguir nada, então eu sugiro tentar discutir essas mudanças com a comunidade. Você pode fazer isso em um par de formas:

http://forum.openstreetmap.org/viewforum.php?id=74

(Fórum dos usuários brasileiros)

https://lists.openstreetmap.org/listinfo/talk-br

(O "talk-br" mailing list)

Um número de pessoas tem tentado entrar em contato com você via discussões changeset:

http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/31943081 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/31943127 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/31943191 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/31944263

É possível que haja um problema com o seu e-mail, que é por isso que eu estou enviando esta mensagem como um que você tem que ler antes de continuar a editar. Uma vez que você ler esta mensagem, você será capaz de editar openstreetmap novamente, mas, por favor, tente conversar com outros mapeadores antes de fazer alterações de grande escala de classificação estrada.

Cumprimentos,

Andy Townsend (SomeoneElse), em nome do Grupo de Trabalho de Dados do OpenStreetMap.

(in English)

Hello User006,

There seems to be some disagreement with the classification of highways around Linhares. For example,

http://www.openstreetmap.org/way/328842747/history

was originally added as "highway=primary". You then changed it to "highway=trunk", somebody changed it back to "highway=primary", you then changed it to "highway=trunk" again, and somebody else changed it back to "highway=primary". Clearly these "backwards and forwards" changes doesn't achieve anything, so I'd suggest trying to discuss these changes with the community. You can do that in a couple of ways:

http://forum.openstreetmap.org/viewforum.php?id=74

(the Brazilian users' forum)

https://lists.openstreetmap.org/listinfo/talk-br

(the "talk-br" mailing list)

A number of people have tried to contact you via changeset discussions:

http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/31943081 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/31943127 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/31943191 http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/31944263

It's possible that there is a problem with your email, which is why I'm sending this message as one that you have to read before continuing to edit. Once you've read this message you'll be able to edit openstreetmap again, but please do try to talk to other mappers before making large scale road classification changes.

Best regards,

Andy Townsend (SomeoneElse) on behalf of OpenStreetMap's Data Working Group.

introducing errors into OSM on purpose is vandalism. Performing vandalism for "research" reasons doesn't make it better.

dear Farooq,

Thank you for your recent attempts to contribute to OpenStreetmap.

However, you have been adding and resolving a lot of notes to the map, marking points of interest where they clearly already exist. Members of the osm-gb community have tried to get in touch via the OpenStreetmap message system, offering advice on how best to add to the map.

This "zero-hour block" means that you must log in once and read your OpenStreetmap messages before you can continue to edit the map.

Thanks

Jo Walsh aka zool, on behalf of the Data Working Group

I've blocked again for repeatedly adding of duplicate / invalid data, in this case http://www.openstreetmap.org/node/3611701986/history , which is clearly the same item as http://www.openstreetmap.org/node/294114509 , and the imagery and footpaths suggest that the previous version was correctly placed and your new version is not.

See http://www.openstreetmap.org/user_blocks/752 , http://www.openstreetmap.org/user_blocks/638 and http://www.openstreetmap.org/user_blocks/606 and links in those for details of previous issues.

Again, please don't hesitate to contact me or anyone else in OSM's data working group by email to data@osmfoundation.org . It is important that as mappers within OSM we work together - I've never seen any communication from you in reply to requests from other mappers in changeset discussion comments, or received any email.

Best Regards,

Andy Townsend, on behalf of the OSM Data Working Group.

Dear user michaelis1888,

you have made a number of edits that the Slovak community found needed an explanation, e.g.

https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/20486433 https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/29707792 https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/32036957 https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/32057091

Dear chelyuskin4,

You have made multiple edits in the South China Sea region adding very fine detail to some of the islands. This detail is far too fine compared to the available compatibly-licensed satellite imagery provided for OpenStreetMap use; you also directly identify incompatible sources from which you have copied.

I am placing a 0 hour block on your account, which means that to continue editing, you must log into the OSM site and acknowledge this message.

Do not continue to use commercial satellite imagery that is not compatible with OpenStreetMap. You may reference this page for more information. Because the data added is from incompatible sources, the changesets have been reverted. In the future, continue to identify the source of any added data...just be sure to use a proper source.

Please do not hesitate to contact me or the Data Working Group at data@osmfoundation.org if you have any questions.

Sincerely,

Ethan aka FTA on behalf of the OSMF Data Working Group

Dear user dk_hk,

you are adding a large amount of name:hu tags to objects around the world. Please stop that for a moment, and explain to the imports mailing list or to data@osmfoundation org what your data source is and how you are adding these names, and especially if you have the local knowledge that enables you to say whether the names you're adding are indeed the right names. (Also, please use the changeset comment field to describe what you're doing - it is there for a reason.)

Thank you
Frederik Ramm a.k.a woodpeck

Hello,

I'm sending this as a "message that has to be read" before editing can continue to draw your attention to the discussion on http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/32767835 and some of your other changesets. Some people have had problems receiving emails from osm.org, and have missed being notified about changeset discussion comments; I'm sending this just in case you have that problem too.

You'll be able to continue editing normally as soon as you have read this message, though of course I would certainly suggest that you try and address the points raised in changeset discussions and answer the questions asked. We all edit the same map and it's important that we all work together and that the valuable contributions of mappers who go out and survey stuff isn't diluted by "mechanical-turk-edits" that simply change valid tags that they do not understand (though no-one, I suspect, is going to argue that changing "color" to "colour" requires a huge amount of discussion beforehand and causes data to be lost.

Note that the mechanical edit policy

http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Automated_Edits_code_of_conduct

contains the following:

"This includes ... use of find-and-replace functionality using a standard editor such as JOSM or using an XAPI service where the changes are not reviewed individually;". I'd take "reviewed individually" to mean more here than just "looking at the tags already on the object without looking at the context".

Best Regards,

Andy Townsend aka SomeoneElse, on behalf of OpenStreetMap's Data Working Group

Dear ddtuga,

I am placing a 0 hour block on your account, meaning you must log in and read this message to continue editing.

You have been introducing many errors into OpenStreetMap with your edits, e.g. removing layer tags from objects, adding strange tags inside ways, and abbreviating already-correct street names. In addition, many members of the local OSM community have attempted to contact you through the OpenStreetMap messaging system and changeset comments offering help on how you can improve your contributions to OSM.

If you have questions about how to map something properly, great resources to consult are the OSM wiki and OSM's Q&A--or feel free to ask for assistance from anyone, including those who have previously reached out. It would be helpful to reply to the changeset comments they have left so things can be resolved.

Lastly, please remember to include descriptive changeset comments with every edit. These comments are a courtesy to help others understand what edits you have made.

Feel free to reach out to either me or the Data Working Group if you have any questions.

Best Regards,

Ethan (FTA) on behalf of the OSMF Data Working Group

Hello and welcome to OpenStreetMap!

As you'll no doubt be aware, OpenStreetMap is about mapping what's there in the real world, and we're all editing the same map, so "mass deletions" such as in http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/33149078 affect everyone.

I notice that local mappers have been in contact in http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/33152447 (comment "This is a joke that I am playing on you") and have also tidied up the problems, so hopefully everything's back to how it was before.

Obviously it's possible that you didn't make these edits at all and someone guessed your password or got access to an unlocked PC, so I'm sending this message as one that has to be read before continuing to edit so that you're aware of it.

If it was a "PC unlocked" accident I'd definitely reply to the changeset discussion on http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/33152447 apologising and explaining what happened so everyone knows - as I said before, we're all editing the same map and need to work together to do that.

If you're looking for some sort of "test server" then you'll find that http://api06.dev.openstreetmap.org/ is exactly that (though I don't think that anyone renders tiles from the data there). If you want an place to map imaginary places, then http://opengeofiction.net/ may be for you.

However, if changes that need to be reverted continue you may need to be blocked from OpenStreetMap.

Best Regards,

Andy Townsend, on behalf of OpenStreetMap's Data Working Group.

Hello,

It has come to the attention of the Data Working Group that you have been deleting or modifying controversial objects. Members of the local Italian community have contacted you, in addition to members of the DWG, through changeset discussions and private OSM messages, to which you haven't replied.

In addition, the changesets in question do not have changeset comments.

In order to work productively with the community as a whole, we ask that you please respond to changeset discussions around the topics in question to encourage discussion around your edits, and that you use changeset comments on your future changesets in order to let others in your local community understand not only what you are changing, but why.

Because you haven't responded to any other communication medium, I am placing this Stop Message in place. That means that you will not be able to edit OSM until you have read and acknowledged this message by logging into osm.org.

Once you do, you will be able to edit again normally.

If you have any questions, please don't hesitate the DWG at data@osmfoundation.org

Thank you,

Serge Wroclawski on behalf of the OSM Data Working Group

reason:
Hola María Jimena,

OpenStreetMap es un proyecto colaborativo y cada aporte es bienvenido, pero no es un lugar para hacer pruebas de mapeamiento, tampoco puede ser usada como si fuera un mapa privado para trazar sus propias rutas. La "ruta desde mi casa hasta CU" no es una información que pertenezca al mapa general del mundo, creo lo entiendas. También hay reglas y convenciones en el uso de los tags; highway=track representa a un camino rural, lo cual no viene al caso.

Por cierto, hay otras formas para trazar sus propias rutas y compartirlas en la web, este es un sitio que permete hacerlo de manera muy sencilla y que hace uso de OpenStreetMap: http://umap.openstreetmap.fr/es/

Tu cuenta está suspendida hasta que leas este mensaje.

Gracias Un saludo

Peda OSMF Data Working Group

Hi María Jimena,

OpenStreetMap is a collaborative project and every contribution is welcome, but keep in mind it is not a place to make tests, nor it is a private map to share your own routes. The "route from my house to the university" is not something you'd expect to see in a general world map, I think you will understand it. There are also rules and conventions behind OSM tagging; highway=track is meant to be a road for agricultural use, which is not the case here.

There are other useful tools to trace your own routes and share them online, this is a user-friendly interface making use of OSM data as background: http://umap.openstreetmap.fr/es/

Your account is temporarily blocked until you read this message.

Thanks,

Peda on behalf of the OSMF Data Working Group

reason: There is no room for SEO content on OpenStreetMap. Your edits have been reverted.

Hello,

I'm sending this message to you as one that has to be read before you continue editing in case there's a problem with your email. You'll be able to edit again immediately after reading it, but please do take heed of the contents:

I (and at least one other user) have tried to get in touch with you about the large-scale edits that you are performing, some of which are plainly wrong.

http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/33438237

was an example of that. You misunderstood the tag used, and because you did not understand it, changed the tag to one that was completely invalid for the feature.

There is a clear code of conduct that must be followed by people making mechanical edits to OpenStreetMap data:

http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Automated_Edits_code_of_conduct

Among the first things that should happen is to document the changes that you're planning to make and to discuss them with other OpenStreetMap mappers. It's important that this happens so that any misunderstandings that you may have can be resolved. This does not seem to have happened at all in the case of your edits - unless you can point out where you disucssed your proposed edits first?

Please note that just because you change a value from a "less common tag" to a "common tag" it does not mean that it actually reflects what is physically present on the ground. Here's an example of that:

http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/33506329

In that changeset http://www.openstreetmap.org/way/322964225 (a hedge) was changed from "natural=bushes" to "natural=scrub". Of course, "natural=bushes" is an unusual tag but not a meaningless one, and in the context of a hedge makes perfect sense. A hedge made out of "scrub" makes very little sense.

I would therefore suggest that you go through all of your mechanical changesets and ask yourself whether the changes that you have made in each case are valid. Where people have commented on those changesets suggesting that something has gone wrong, it's important that you reply and explain what happened.

There will, of course, always be cases where mappers, especially new mappers, "get things wrong". Rather than just changing the a tag to something that you are familiar with, it's important that you try and understand how things got to that point. Here's an example of that:

http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/33514376

Here it looks to me like a mapper was trying to change "place=locality" to "natural=fell" and made a mistake. Rather than just changing it back to the wrong value (which you did) a better approach would have been to contact them with a polite changeset discussion comment, explain what the problem is, and offer to help fix it. If that doesn't work, you can add an OpenStreetMap note so that other local mappers who are familiar with the area can check and correct the data if necessary.

OpenStreetMap is a shared database - we all edit the same data. If data that people have surveyed is changed to something that is wrong by people who have not surveyed the area, it makes OpenStreetMap data as a whole less useful for everyone concerned. We have to work together to create a better map. Please, therefore, go through the changes that you have made and check that they're valid, and please explain them where questions have been asked in changeset discussion comments. Finally, you must use meaningful changeset comments. "attrib correction" is not a meaningful comment - it does not explain what you changed and why.

Failure to do this may result in you being prevented from editing OpenStreetMap for a short period of time, or even longer.

Best Regards,

Andy Townsend (SomeoneElse), on behalf of OpenStreetMap's Data Working Group.

If you'd like to contact the DWG via email directly, you can always do so via data@osmfoundation.org .

reason:
Hi Conor,

Three weeks ago people made complaints about a number of changes that you'd made to OpenStreetMap. As a result, we asked you to be more careful and (if the problems were accidental) explain what had happened.

Unfortunately since then there have been some more complaints, about http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/33500805 and http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/33646862 . OpenStreetMap isn't the place for experimenting with "what if this road was like that" - it's for recording things as they are.

One more thing - please, on any edits, do use meaningful changeset comments explaining why you've made a certain change. For example, on a changeset like http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/33646862 , you should have explained why you think that part of the R917 is called Station Road not Spencer Street (despite it being the continuation of Spencer Street towards Spencer Manor just to the southwest).

Obviously we don't want to stop anyone from contributing to OpenStreetMap but if problematical changes that need to be reverted continue we may have to do so.

Best Regards,

Andy Townsend, on behalf of OpenStreetMap's Data Working Group.

Hello and welcome to OpenStreetMap!

I'm sending this message as one that has to be read before continuing editing just in case you're not receiving emails for any reason. A couple of mappers have tried to get in touch via changeset discussion comments (see for example https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/33802064 and https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/33809000 ) and haven't had a reply. It looks as if you might be using some sort of out-of-date data source.

If you have been receiving email messages from changeset discussions it's easy to reply - just click the "changeset" link at the bottom of the message and you'll be taken to the website where there's a text box with "comment" below it.

If you haven't been receiving email messages you might want to sort your email out, but in the meantime you can see who's tried to get in touch by looking at the list at https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/beatrice%20jones/history and seeing where there's a non-zero value to the right of the changeset information.

One more thing - it's really helpful to other mappers to add a description of changes that you're making (it doesn't have to be a huge paragraph - https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/33631443 is one of mine, for example). That way people can see why changes were made and what the source was.

Anyway, hope you don't mind me mentioning this - just trying to help. Any questions just ask - you might find http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Contact_channels helpful here. If you want to get in touch with other mappers in GB quickly you might also want to try the #osm-gb IRC channel - see http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/IRC for that.

Best Regards,

Andy Townsend (SomeoneElse), on behalf of OSM's Data Working Group.

Hello mustafa_geo,

I'm sending you this message because there seems to be a bit of a misunderstanding about OSM nodes and ways.

You previously added a duplicate Interlink Express in Alfreton at https://www.openstreetmap.org/node/3773308357/history , which I deleted (see discussion on https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/34448963 ) and you added it back as https://www.openstreetmap.org/node/3799210861/history .

There should only be one thing in OSM for each thing in the real world - see http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/One_feature,_one_OSM_element . A duplication of things as both nodes and ways will mean that anyone counting things in OSM will end up with twice as many as there are in real life. When you're extracting data from OSM you'll need to consider ways as well as nodes (and also possibly relations - see http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Elements ). If you're using a command-line based extraction, Osmconvert ( http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Osmconvert ) already supports an "--all-to-nodes" parameter to allow you to only worry about nodes downstream; if you're processing the data directly then just handle tags on ways in the same way as nodes.

I'm sending this as a message that must be read before continuing editing because it's possible (if there's a mail misconfiguration) that you might not have seen the email from the comments on https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/34448963 and those from other mappers. You can see other changesets with discussion comments on them by going to https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/mustafa_geo/history and looking for non-zero numbers. You'll be able to edit as normal immediately after reading this message.

A couple of other useful links:

https://help.openstreetmap.org/ has lots of "data extraction" questions on it - whatever you're trying to do, someone might have asked about it before.

https://lists.openstreetmap.org/listinfo/talk-gb is the "talk-gb" mailing list, one of the main places where GB discussion takes place. Northern Ireland is covered by https://lists.openstreetmap.org/listinfo/talk-ie . People will be able to answer any questions you might have there.

http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/IRC is widely used: irc://irc.oftc.net/osm-gb usually has people in it during the daytime.

More general contact information is at http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Contact_channels .

Any questions, please don't hesitate to ask - either using one of those options or via data@osmfoundation.org .

Best Regards,

Andy Townsend (SomeoneElse) on behalf of OpenStreetMap's Data Working Group.

Dear user Giorgi1967,

you seem to have misunderstood how OSM works. A place can have many names in many different languages, that's what our "name:xx" (with xx being a language code) tags are for. For example, the town of ბიჭვინთა (Bichvinta) is called "Pezonda" in Italian. This was recorded in OSM, and you removed it, along with a host of other name tags on different objects.

Additionally, your edits seem politically motivated ("All toponyms in Georgia must be and will be in Georgian."); OpenStreetMap does not subscribe to that rule, but instead attempts to map what is on the ground in a specific place. This means that if you enter a town in Georgia and the city sign has a Russian name on it, then that's what'd OSM would map as the primary name.

Please consult https://wiki.osmfoundation.org/w/images/d/d8/DisputedTerritoriesInformation.pdf for further details about naming.

Your edits amount to vandalism and will be removed. Please do [b]not[/b] attempt to recreate them without first arguing your case with the wider OSM community. If you should receive changeset comments from users, as happened in http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/35196194 for example, don't ignore them - they are a sign that you might be doing something wrong.

OSM has all the information to create a map with exclusively Georgian names, and if you wish to do that, I'm sure the community at help.openstreetmap.org will be willing to tell you how.

For the OSMF Data Working Group: Frederik Ramm a.k.a. woodpeck

Daher gibt es auch fleißige Mapper, die versuchen solche Fehler zu finden und zu beheben. are you the same person also running the account Giorgi1967? Both of you seem to edit place names in Abkhazia and South Ossetia, applying Georgian names although the Georgian language is rarely used in these areas and most signs will not be in Georgian.

Please understand that OSM maps what is "on the ground". The fact that these regions are officially part of Georgia does not mean that all place names have to be Georgian in OSM.

I am afraid I will have to block your account and revert your edits for now. Please contact data@osmfoundation.org if you wish to discuss this. OpenStreetMap can certainly benefit from more Georgian names added in these regions but as far as we can see, putting them in the "name" tag is a political statement that we cannot accept.

Thank you
Frederik Ramm aka woodpeck
OSMF Data Working Group

Please, stop!

You are carrying out a series of mechanical edits without giving any thought to the data that you are actually changing.

Several hours, several changesets and many thousands of object edits ago I suggested on http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/35588464 that you really shouldn't be changing shops that you have not surveyed.

Taking a single recent change as an example

http://www.openstreetmap.org/way/183385490

what does "brand:wikidata=Q38076"? How do you know that this restaurant is actually part of this brand, and not just similarly named?

Similarly, you have added "franchise:wikidata=Q38076", but how do you know that this shop even is a franchise (McDonald's is roughly 75% franchise and 25% not if you believe wikipedia).

As per http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Automated_Edits_code_of_conduct mechanical edits like this should be discussed beforehand before they take place. You have not done this.

You will be able to continue editing once you have read this message, but please do not carry out any more undiscussed mechanical edits.

Best Regards,

Andy Townsend (SomeoneElse) on behalf of OpenStreetMap's Data Working Group.

Hallo openmarcel,

leider scheinen dich private Nachrichten nicht zuverlässig zu erreichen. So hast du z.B. auf meine private Nachricht an dich nicht reagiert und auch einige der neueren Changeset-Kommentare nicht beantwortet bzw. nicht darauf reagiert.

Das ist für andere Benutzer teilweise ein großes Ärgernis, da sie diese Changesets dann längerfristig überwachen müssen um auf eine Reaktion von dir zu warten bzw. auch deine Changesets regelmäsig kontrollieren und gegebenenfalls verbessern müssen. So sehr ich deine guten und vielen Änderungen schätze, so sehr wünsche ich mir, dass du nicht gleichzeitig andere durch deine Nicht-Reaktion demotivierst. Ich bitte dich, das dringend zu ändern und die dir gegebenen Tipps und Hinweise anzunehmen und insbesondere auch dauerhaft umzusetzen oder, falls du mit einem Hinweis nicht einverstanden bist, ihn mit dem entsprechenden Benutzer zu diskutieren.

Noch wichtiger ist mir allerdings, dass du auf die folgenden vier Changesets reagierst, da mit ihnen unter Umständen urheberrechtlich geschützte Daten nach OpenStreetMap gelangt sind:

https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/35123065

https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/35121559

https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/34990866

https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/34977424

Ich sperre dich daher erneut, bis du diese Nachricht gelesen hast und bitte dich, dich hier etwas mehr in die Gemeinschaft zu integrieren. Mappen bedeutet eben nicht nur, für sich alleine hinmappen, sondern auch mal gemeinsam zu arbeiten.

Vielen Dank,

Peter Barth aka Peda

i.A. OSMF Data Working Group

Hallo openmarcel,

leider muss ich nun zu härteren Maßnahmen greifen:

  • Ich sperre dich vorläufig für 48 Stunden
  • Ich verpflichte dich alle Fragen zu beantworten, in denen du zur Urheberschaft der Daten befragt wurdest
  • Ich verpflichte dich, alle Hinweise von MarkusHD anzunehmen und umzusetzen bevor du irgendetwas anderes machst, also weiter mappst! (d.h. vor allem unnötige name-Tags löschen, doppeltes Tagging entfernen, stoppen mit unnötigem Löschen und neu Anlegen von POIs, usw.)

Ich habe das jetzt mehrfach erklärt, ich erkläre es aber nochmal: Wir sind ein Communityprojekt, das unter anderem von der Gemeinschaft lebt. Ein Projekt, in dem es essentiell ist, auf Kommentare zu antworten und einzugehen, sonst funktioniert das langfristig nicht. Ein Projekt, in dem es auch wichtig ist, andere Mapper weder zu demotivieren, noch ihnen unnötig Extraarbeit zu generieren. Ein Projekt in dem eben auch kommuniziert werden muss!

Solltest du ein Problem haben, deine Changesetkommentare zu finden, kannst du auch einfach deine Änderungsliste durchsehen. Alle mit einer größeren Zahl als 0 in der Sprechblase enthalten einen Kommentar an dich.

Solltest du das Gefühl haben unfair behandelt zu werden oder unfaire Komentare erhalten zu haben, steht es dir frei, dich bei mir oder direkt bei der Data Working Group zu melden. Keine Option ist es, einzelne oder alle Kommentare zu ignorieren und ohne vorherige vollständige Klärung aller offenen Punkte weiter zu mappen.

So leid es mir tut, dass ich nun doch härter durchgreifen muss, so wichtig ist diese Maßnahme. Das heißt auch, dass ich bei weiteren Verstößen deinen Account weiter bzw. längerfristig sperren werde und im schlimmsten Fall sogar (größere) Teile deiner Änderungen revertieren (entfernen) werde. Vielen Dank für dein Verständnis.

Viele Grüße,

Peter Barth aka Peda

i.A. OSMF Data Working Group

Andy Townsend (SomeoneElse) on behalf of OpenStreetMap's Data Working Group.

dear mapper abc26324,

I write on behalf of the Data Working Group of the OpenStreetMap Foundation.

There has been some upset amongst the UK community of mappers regarding some of your edits to OpenStreetMap; particularly those edits adding relations to roads where it is generally agreed they are not needed - there are no roads in the UK with multiple reference numbers that need route relations.

A number of UK community members have tried to get in touch with you via changeset discussion to air their concerns and ask for further explanation, but haven't heard anything back from you. For example at http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/35737307 there are several people asking for an explanation and pointing you at the relevant discussion on the talk-gb mailing list.

Thus I am applying what is known as a zero-hour block to your account; this obliges you to log in to OpenStreetMap and read this message before you can continue to edit the map.

Please make an effort to respond to the concerns of other mappers in the community via the form of changeset discussions or the mailing list forum. It would also be good if you could leave descriptive comments on your changesets, as the default "(no comment)" doesn't help other mappers to follow along and make sense of what you are doing ( as noted in this discussion here: http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/35737381 )

cheers,

Jo Walsh aka zool On behalf of the Data Working Group

reason:
Hello, and welcome to OpenStreetMap.

OpenstreetMap is a project for mapping things as they exist in the real world. It's not for "test edits" so see how things show up on the map, or for things that you might like to exist. There's no motorway in Cornwall near the one that you added in http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/36529465 (I'm sure plenty of people in Cornwall would like a motorway that joins them to the rest of the world, although one that goes around in a circle wouldn't be much use).

You're welcome to contribute to OSM but please do so positively:

o Add things that do exist, not things that don't.

o Do make sure that you explain the edits that you're making in changeset comments ("dslfedsf " on http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/36529465 is not an explanation).

o Do please reply to other mappers in changeset discussions when they ask you questions, for example in http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/36458698 .

o Don't just close notes without any explanation, like you did with http://www.openstreetmap.org/note/312383

I'm sending this message as one that has to be read before continuing editing just in case you're not receiving emails for any reason. You'll be able to carry on mapping as soon as you've read it, but please do contribute positively (as described above) or you may be prevented from updating OpenStreetMap in the future.

Best Regards,

Andy Townsend (SomeoneElse) on behalf of OpenStreetMap's Data Working Group. To contact the Data Working Group at any time, email data@osmfoundation.org .
