Dear user fedc,

I am sending you this message in order to notify you of complaints that Data Working Group have received about your editing.

You are not blocked from OSM and you can continue your work as soon as you have read this message.

However, many members of the Italian OSM community have issues with your mapping, and especially with the way you seem to evade any public discussion about it. You do reply to individual messages but not to public changeset comments, and you don't participate on the mailing list or forum; for a prolific mapper like yourself, it would be prudent to explain yourself publicly when questioned rather than send individual messages, so that others can take part in the discussion.

People are concerned about the way in which you often delete data from the map in order to re-trace it in a supposedly "better" way, but you are too careless about it and you lose information, for example you deleted a named soccer pitch here

http://www.openstreetmap.org/way/124198134/history

and then re-created it without a name

http://www.openstreetmap.org/way/398448795

You should really only delete and re-draw things in exceptional circumstances; out of respect for the work of others, if something just needs a little geometric refinement, modify the object instead of throwing out what others have done completely!

Here's an instance where you removed a historic=castle designation without any comment and replaced it with building=yes:

http://www.openstreetmap.org/way/124206392/history

Here is a building you created as a multipolygon

http://www.openstreetmap.org/relation/5860719

but you deleted seven individual buildings that were there before, and so on, and so on. And all this with a changeset comment of "Continuo con le campiture" which is next to worthless and does not adequately describe the edits made here.

Your edits are not wrong in themselves but they are so wide-ranging that you are essentially putting your mark all of the Milan area and beyond, mapping it to your personal standards and likings, and you are doing so much of that that other mappers feel you are rejecting and overwriting their efforts.

Please try to see OSM as a social activity - engage in public discussion. When someone writes a changeset discussion entry to one of your changesets, answer publicly. When your work is discussed on the forum or mailing list, participate. When five other mappers tell you not to do something, then stop doing it or at least think about it for a while, as they might be right! OpenStreetMap is not your personal playground where you can do whatever you think is right.

Thank you
Frederik Ramm aka woodpeck
OSMF Data Working Group

Hallo fufzich,

mehrere Community-Mitglieder haben Dich bereits darauf hinzuweisen versucht, dass Betretungsverbote bei uns in OSM nicht durch Löschung der "verbotenen" Wege oder Flächen, sondern durch entsprechende Abbildung der Betretungsverbote (z.B. "access=no") dargestellt werden.

Löscht man die "verbotenen" Wege einfach, so kommt der nächste und malt den Weg vom Luftbild wieder ab, weil er von dem Verbot nichts weiss. Eine saubere Modellierung des Verbots ist also für seine Einhaltung zielführender als der Versuch, die Existenz "verbotener" Wege ganz aus OSM herauszuhalten.

Links zur Diskussion im Forum wurden Dir mitgeteilt, dort wird man Dir gerne weiterhelfen!

Ich hoffe auf Deine Einsicht und weitere konstruktive Mitarbeit, weise Dich aber vorsorglich auch darauf hin, dass vorsätzliche und regelwidrige Datenveränderung bei OSM in Deutschland als Gesetzesverstoß geahndet werden kann!

Diese Nachricht ist mit einer "0-Stunden-Sperre" verbunden; Du kannst sofort weiterarbeiten, wenn Du sie gelesen hast. Wir tun das, um sicherzustellen, dass Dich die Nachricht auch erreicht - da vergangene Versuche der Community, mit Dir in einen Dialog zu treten, ja leider fehlgeschlagen sind.

Viele Grüße
Frederik Ramm
OSMF Data Working Group

Hello 00crashtest, welcome to OpenStreetMap!

I'm sending this message as one that has to be read in case you haven't been seeing the message that people have been leaving on your changesets. Most or all of your recent edits in London have had to be reverted; there have previously been similar problems elsewhere (eg. Hong Kong - https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/36953751 ).

It can be difficult to get the hang of things with OpenStreetMap; and as you've only been editing for a few weeks it's understandable that you're still learning. However, there are a couple of things that you can do to help yourself:

1) One is to trying "starting small". Try mapping shops local to you, or things in a local park. That'll help you to get the hang of things, and understand that sometimes it can be difficult transferring what's in the real world to OpenStreetMap.

2) If you think that something in a particular area is wrong, (for example https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/37778257 ) try contacting the local community and explaining the problem. If you don't know where to start when contacting anyone, try the #osm channel on IRC - see http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/IRC for details.

3) Please do always use changeset comments explaining the details of any changes and your source. Some of your changeset do have changeset comments, but some, such as https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/37801676 , do not.

4) When people contact you via changeset discussions such as on https://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/36953751 please do have the courtesy to reply. OpenStreetMap is a collaborative project; we all have to work together to create the best map. If you have not seen these messages before please check that your email within OSM is configured correctly.

You'll be able to continue mapping as soon as you've read this message but please do try and be a bit more careful in the future.

Best Regards,

Andy Townsend (SomeoneElse) on behalf of OpenStreetMap's Data Working Group.

Hello, dear etajin.

You add many Japanese names in Russia (for example, for villages) [1]. It's bad idea because Russian villages have no Japanese names. But, for example, the capital of Russia Moscow has Japanese name. In Russia there is no Japanese community which could use the Japanese names. Please, read wiki page [http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Names].

Avoid transliteration

Transliteration is the process of taking a name in one language, and simply changing letters from one script to another. In general we should avoid doing this with tags in the OpenStreetMap database. Everything with a name could have auto-generated transliterations, so not just city names, but every road, and every cafe! This kind of automatic augmenting with data is best left for data users. For example, Sven Geggus has demonstrated the principle of rendering with auto-generated transliterations. We want to avoid adding in tags into our database for every named object via automated or semi-automated Import.

Instead we only put commonly used names in other languages into the database. While we typically think of these as translations, in most cases names that fit this criteria are not literal translations, example: the lake that the city of Geneva lies on is in French (Geneva is a French speaking city) Lac Leman, in German Genfersee. These are names which have been used by people on the ground, speaking in different languages (In general we're following Good practice#Map what's on the ground)

For example, small towns in England probably don't have a special Russian name, unless there is a local Russian community or something. Their names can all be transliterated into Russian script, but it's not a good idea to add lots and lots of tags to all the towns in England containing these transliterated names.

Also you ignore questions and comments from Russian contributors [2,3]. Please, answer, when there are questions for you.

Vladimir Marshinin
Data Working Group

  2. http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/37622730
  3. http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/37435785

Bitte verwende in Zukunft aussagekräftige (!) Changeset-Kommentare (s.a. http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/DE:Good_changeset_comments), und bitte ignoriere es nicht einfach, wenn andere Mapper Dir schreiben und Deine Arbeit hinterfragen. Meist gibt es dafür einen guten Grund!

Пожалуйста, не добавляйте бесполезные заметки. Если это ваши персональные заметки, то добавляйте их в своё персональное устройство, но не в OpenStreetMap.

Владимир Маршинин
Рабочая группа по данным

(english version)

Hello, dear contributor.

You add useless notes in OpenStreetMap [1,2,3]. I have written to you about it and I have asked you to not add such notes anymore [4].

Unfortunately, you have ignored these words and have continued to add and to reopen useless notes [5,6,7]. I remind you, that intentionally ignoring the consensus norms of the OpenStreetMap community is vandalism [8].

Please, don't add useless notes. If these notes are your personal then add them in your personal device, but not in OpenStreetMap.

Vladimir Marshinin
Data Working Group
